prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want my hair fixed, for free, by the hairdresser?
[What I showed her](http://imgur.com/KmuiLRL)


[What I got](http://imgur.com/gEiWAi4)


I asked my stylist to do a light brown rose gold, and emphasized that I wanted it a light brown, warm color.

I showed her the picture more than a week in advance of the appointment so she had time to get any colors she didn’t have. 

I told her multiple times I wanted a light brown.  I know you can’t perfectly match the picture, but I think I made it obvious I wanted more brown than red in my hair.  I would have been fine without the rose tint.  My hair was bleach blonde to begin with.

She’s going to try to fix it but I don’t think I should have to pay, this is clearly not what I asked for.  Am I the asshole?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario is about a hairdresser not doing the correct color. The author showed a picture of a light brown rose gold and emphasized wanting light brown, warm color. The result was something more red, which the author didn't like.

First, I need to consider the key points. The author communicated their desired color multiple times, even sent a picture in advance. The hairdresser didn't get the color right, leading to a result that's not what was agreed upon. The author now wants the fix for free.

Is the author in the wrong? Well, they did make their request clear. Even if the hairdresser tried, if they didn't follow the instructions, that's on them. The client isn't at fault for the mistake. Also, the hairdresser should be responsible for fixing their error without charging the client. So the answer should be B (No, the author isn't in the wrong). The hairdresser messed up, so the client shouldn't have to pay for the fix.
